topic.title: zeronet.py: error: too few arguments

Hey everybody,

I get the following error while trying to run ZeroNet on my server:

```bash
./ZeroNet.sh --ui_ip <server_ip> --ui_restrict <my_ip>

```

topic.title: Big Site Feature
topic.body:
Hi all,

I was thinking about having a special feature in ZeroNet for big sites. Basically, make servers seed big sites and disable seeding from clients. That way, we could have, per example, videos, images, and more hosted on a couple of servers. When there enough servers seeding, let the user choose to seed or not, saving disk space and bandwidth. Everybody *wanting* to seed could still seed, but others are not forced to.

When one or two servers are down, automatically re-enable seeding from all clients. There should always be at least X copies of every file available. Like 20 or so.

Maybe add a functionality to the client prioritising connections to servers as well.

topic.title: A ZeroWiki for docs ?
topic.body:
Wouldn't it be nice to have a zite dedicated to zeronet docs and how-to's ?

We could re-host the [docs](http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-make-zeronet-work-with-tor-under-linux) (CN) there as well. (Even if there is a mirror already).

We could also start to write how-to's, link to known blogs, etc. Have a "get discovering" page for sites that are a must (additionally to the ones linked on the home page by default). Everybody will have a chance to contribute.

1_1Hk3VC1SpvpXdhSYFPsQRowJC1mDnWESoX.body: Personally, I don't like the idea of a shared CDN. These files weight a couple of KB at maximum, and every site having its own JQuery has an advantage: decentralisation. What happens if the owner of a CDN modifies the file ? Everybody using that CDN will be doomed.

1_17M2Zwbk1drijqtf94fDyBGm7XucVrYPFC.body: If you modify a zite's code, you won't be able to seed the files you edited, because it doesn't match what the original author signed. The only way to modify a zite and send it to every peer is to sign it with the zite's private key.

> [crq](#comment_10_17M2Zwbk1drijqtf94fDyBGm7XucVrYPFC): Alright, thanks :)How does stuff like posting here work then? it also changes content.

It doesn't actually change the site's source code itself. When this site's author made the zite, he specified that every user id (mine is kindlyfire@zeroid.bit per example) can have it's own directory. You and the admin are the only persons who can write in that directory. The admin can also specify a maximum size, which is 40K here.

When a users opens the zite, ZeroNet will build a database containing everything in every user's directory. That way, if you publish content in your directory, it will get published in everybody's local database. *But*: you can only edit *your own* directory, not the one of somebody else.

Hope that clears some things up :) docs need some clearing up on that too.

To be honest, a meta-proxy is just as vulnerable as a real proxy. (I run https://proxy1.zn.kindlyfire.me )
If the meta-proxy goes down, you will have to change all the url's anyway.

Even if you make a zite which stores urls from proxies, there's no way to guarantee that it will stay up. Personally, https://proxy1.zn.kindlyfire.me can run for 1 year, without downtime, without me even connecting to it, and It'll probably stay that way. (I have it monitored every 1 min though -- so I get a notification if something happens)

Edit: since June 12, 9:58 am, it runs without interruption (not even a reboot)
